Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Senior Official in Regime with Human Rights Violations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Male applicant served as Lieutenant Colonel (rank 6 of 17) in the Iraqi army under Saddam Hussein's regime; Officer used military hierarchy charts and consulted War Crimes Unit to assess seniority.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of duty of fairness during assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants were given opportunity to respond; no deficiency noted
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Position fell within top half of military hierarchy; decision was reasonable and transparent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Violation of human or international rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on association with regime committing human rights violations
Crimes.Outcome: No violation found by reviewing body; application dismissed
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Male applicant’s role as senior military official in Saddam Hussein’s regime
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights standards
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Assessment by Immigration Officer with input from War Crimes Unit
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Regime engaged in human rights violations
Crimes.Credibility: Applicants had opportunity to respond; credibility not directly challenged
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed inadequate due to nature of regime

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: s. 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Mr. Yahie's past role in the Somali government
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 35(1)(b); Regulation 16(d)
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision remitted for reconsideration
Credibility: Officer did not adequately assess credibility or role influence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to being a prescribed senior official in the service of a government engaging in human rights violations
Violation_Type: Being a senior official in a government engaged in human rights violations
Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Regulation 16(d)
Application_Facts: Mr. Yahie was Director of Human Resources in Somalia's Ministry of Planning, managed 10-15 staff, worked on social projects, reported to higher officials
Residency_Compliance: Application denied based on inadmissibility grounds
Procedural_Issue: Lack of transparency and inadequate reasoning by the Officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to analyze level of influence or hierarchy
Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient assessment of whether role met 'senior official' criteria
Decision_Outcome: Original decision set aside; remanded for reconsideration by another officer
Outcome: Denial of permanent residence overturned on judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different immigration officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of 'senior official' under s. 35(1)(b) and Regulation 16(d)
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to provide sufficient analysis linking Mr. Yahie’s role to significant influence or benefit

Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on senior government position
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant held a senior position in the Rwandan government during a period of systematic human rights violations; worked closely with individuals implicated in genocide
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment of procedural fairness in immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Organizational hierarchy data, association with implicated individuals
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Senior role in government involved in human rights violations meets criteria for inadmissibility under section 35(1)(b)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility for violating human or international rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on association with human rights-violating government
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Paragraph 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Inadmissible due to senior official status during human rights violations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Senior position in Rwandan government during systematic human rights violations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights standards
Crimes.Protected_Group: Victims of genocide and human rights abuses in Rwanda
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Tutsi population and political opponents during Rwandan genocide
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Rwandan government failed to protect targeted groups
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Systematic human rights violations including genocide
Crimes.Credibility: No allegation of personal involvement in crimes; credibility not challenged
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systematic and gross human rights violations
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Rwandan government officials and associated actors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a prescribed senior official in the service of a government engaging in systematic or gross human rights violations
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility as a prescribed senior official in a rights-violating regime
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Paragraph 35(1)(b) and section 16(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Found inadmissible due to senior role in Rwandan government
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Held senior position in Minesupres from 1990 to 1993 during human rights violations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights law
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration officer, Federal Court of Canada
Crimes.Protected_Group: Victims of genocide and systemic abuse in Rwanda
Crimes.Credibility: Not disputed; focus on structural responsibility
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Gross and systematic human rights violations
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Senior officials and structures of the Rwandan government

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on association with a regime involved in human rights violations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Holway served as a brigadier in Afghanistan's Marxist regime, which was designated for gross human rights violations; claimed a clerical role, but this was found implausible given his rank and position in the chain of command
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged misrepresentation or implausibility regarding the nature of military duties
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation of breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Military rank, historical designation of regime, chain of command implications
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting clerical role claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found Mr. Holway's claim of a non-operational clerical role not credible
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Senior military rank in a designated abusive regime makes individual inadmissible; claim of non-involvement not credible

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to association with a regime committing gross human rights violations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Seniority in a regime designated for gross human rights abuses
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights law principles
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refusal of application by immigration authorities
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Canadian visa officer and immigration authorities
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Former brigadier in Afghan Marxist regime seeking entry to Canada
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Civilians subjected to human rights abuses under the Afghan Marxist regime
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Regime was officially designated as engaging in gross human rights violations
Crimes.Risk_Factor: High likelihood of involvement in human rights abuses due to senior military rank
Crimes.Credibility: Officer found claim of clerical role not credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Regime did not provide adequate protection; was itself the perpetrator
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Association with systemic human rights violations
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Afghanistan's Marxist regime and its military structure
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Political opposition, civilians, and others targeted by the regime

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on association with regime involved in human rights violations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was a former lieutenant colonel in the Iraqi Army during Saddam Hussein's regime; served in a non-combat role but held rank within top half of military hierarchy
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Fairness letter issued by officer; opportunity to respond provided
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Decision made by Canadian immigration officer under IRPA jurisdiction
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Military service details, CBSA report, ENF 18 guidelines, applicant’s statements
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer accepted rank and position but did not require proof of personal involvement in abuses
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Rank of lieutenant colonel placed applicant in top half of military hierarchy, meeting definition of 'senior official' regardless of personal blameworthiness
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer at Canadian Embassy, supported by CBSA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a prescribed senior official in the service of a government engaging in systematic or gross human rights violations
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on status as senior official in abusive regime
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Paragraph 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Service as lieutenant colonel in Iraqi Army under Saddam Hussein’s regime
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 16 (definition of 'senior official'), Section 33 (standard of proof)
Crimes.Institutional_Action: CBSA recommendation and immigration officer assessment leading to inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Immigration Officer, Federal Court
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Former military officer seeking permanent residency
Crimes.Protected_Group: Not applicable – focus on perpetrator status
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Civilians subjected to human rights violations under Saddam Hussein’s regime
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Iraq under Saddam Hussein engaged in systematic human rights violations
Crimes.Risk_Factor: High-ranking military officials associated with oppressive regime
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant's rank and service verified; personal role not exonerating under law
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systematic and gross human rights violations
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Iraqi government and military under Saddam Hussein

Crimes.Crime_Name: Violation of human or international rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to association with human rights-abusing regime
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Paragraph 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Senior military rank in regime known for human rights abuses
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, definitions of 'senior official' and standard of 'reasonable grounds to believe'
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found reasonable; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Assessment by immigration officer using ENF 18 and CBSA input
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), CBSA, Federal Court
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Lieutenant colonel in Iraqi Army applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Protected_Group: Civilians in Iraq under Saddam Hussein’s rule
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Political dissidents, ethnic groups, perceived opponents of regime
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State protection unavailable; state itself was perpetrator
Crimes.Risk_Factor: High-level position in repressive military structure
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant’s service confirmed; denial of combat role not sufficient to negate seniority
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Regime lacked rule of law and committed widespread abuses
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Gross and systematic human rights violations
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Iraqi Armed Forces under Ba'athist regime

Application_Facts: Raad Khalid Lutfi, a lieutenant colonel in the Iraqi air force, was alleged to be a senior official in the Iraqi government; divorce claimed as convenience but aimed to help ex-wife leave Iraq
Misrepresentation_Element: Allegation of convenience divorce for immigration purposes, unsubstantiated
Procedural_Issue: Immigration officer's decision lacked evidentiary support
Evidence_Used: Military rank (lieutenant colonel), nature of role, purpose of divorce
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence that Lutfi was a senior official or that divorce was for immigration benefit
Credibility_Assessment: Divorce not deemed fraudulent; motive was humanitarian
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded for rehearing
Decision_Rationale: No evidence Lutfi was a prescribed senior official or committed misrepresentation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility for being a prescribed senior official in the service of a government engaging in human rights violations
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on association with human rights-violating government
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged status as senior official in Iraqi government
Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration officer, Federal Court of Canada
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian immigration law
Individual_Status_or_Claim: Lieutenant colonel in Iraqi Air Force, aircraft maintenance engineer
State_Protection_Assessment: Iraqi government assessed as engaging in human rights violations
Risk_Factor: Association with government accused of human rights abuses
Credibility: Lutfi not shown to have significant influence or benefit from regime
Risk_Nature: Alleged indirect complicity due to position

Legal_Issue: Fairness and procedural correctness of visa officer's decision on education points
Evidence_Assessment: Visa officer failed to fully consider specialized training evidence
Decision_Outcome: 20 points awarded for Education criterion instead of 25 or 22
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's professional qualifications as an Iranian ophthalmologist
Legal_Rule: Visa officer decisions reviewed for reasonableness; procedural fairness issues subject to correctness review
Standard_of_Review: Correctness (due to alleged procedural fairness violation)
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to properly assess education credentials and specialized training
Outcome_on_Merits: Visa officer's decision found procedurally unfair
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical degree classification, specialized training documentation
Legal_Framework: Canadian administrative law, IRPA, principles of procedural fairness
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of education and professional training
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, re-evaluation by another visa officer
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded for revaluation

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had a removal order with a stay granted by IAD until June 2011; citizenship judge made a determination in September 2010 before final decision on removal order.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge proceeded without waiting for final determination of admissibility hearing, violating procedural fairness and statutory requirement.
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Citizenship judge lacked jurisdiction under s. 14(1.1) while removal order was pending final determination.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to pending removal order despite stay.
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal allowed; original decision set aside and remanded to a different citizenship judge.
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of citizenship application by a different judge after IAD final decision
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for questions of law, reasonableness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by making a determination while removal order was pending final adjudication, contrary to statutory bar in s. 14(1.1).

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had a removal order stayed by IAD, awaiting final determination; citizenship judge decided prematurely in September 2010.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Determination made before final resolution of admissibility, violating statutory timing requirements.
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Lack of jurisdiction under subsection 14(1.1) during pendency of admissibility proceedings.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to pending removal order despite IAD stay.
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal allowed; decision set aside and referred back for redetermination by a different judge.
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Appeal under Federal Courts Act and Citizenship Act
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remand for redetermination after finalization of removal order process
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of subsection 14(1.1) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness regarding jurisdictional error, reasonableness on procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by acting prematurely; final determination on removal order required prior to citizenship assessment.

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee status claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that Jamaica provides adequate state protection for women fearing violence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Adequate state protection requires both will and capacity to effectively implement laws protecting citizens from harm
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, matter remanded for redetermination by a different officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed; focus on systemic failure rather than individual credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: U.S. State Department reports on police reluctance and violence against women
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of violence from deported partner in Jamaica
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inadequate implementation of protective laws despite their existence
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider evidence of ineffective state protection
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Existence of both governmental will and capacity to protect
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of police reluctance and widespread violence against women
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Adequate state protection requires effective implementation of laws
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant's fear of domestic violence upon return
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board's decision set aside, case remanded

Crimes.Governing_Law: Adequate state protection requires both will and capacity to implement laws
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and claimed refugee status due to fear of violence
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not directly alleged; focus on protection concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Proper assessment of state protection in home country
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of Immigration Refugee Board over refugee claims
Crimes.Evidence_Used: U.S. State Department report on violence against women and police inaction
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to address evidence of ineffective law enforcement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; claim rejected on state protection grounds
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision set aside, remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Refugee protection based on gender-based violence risk
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Effective implementation of laws required for adequate state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board focused on laws without assessing enforcement

Crimes.Victim_Status: Female applicant with history of abuse
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: History of violence, deportation of perpetrator increasing risk
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat of serious harm or death
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm due to lack of state intervention
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Ongoing and specific threat from ex-partner
Crimes.Threat_Source: Former partner with history of violence
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on relationship and gender
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient – supported by U.S. reports and personal circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as credible by reviewing court
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Refugee Convention grounds: membership in particular social group (women fearing domestic violence)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of rejection of refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in assessing adequacy of state protection in Jamaica
Crimes.Governing_Law: Adequate state protection requires both will and capacity to enforce laws
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, case remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Evidence_Type: U.S. State Department report on police reluctance and gender-based violence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Refugee Convention
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution due to domestic violence and inadequate state protection
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Government’s failure to effectively implement protective laws
Crimes.Application_Error: Board ignored evidence of ineffective enforcement of laws
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Effective implementation standard for state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of police reluctance and systemic failures in protecting women
Crimes.Legal_Standard: State must have both will and capacity to protect
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant’s membership in a particular social group (women fearing domestic violence)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision set aside, remanded for new hearing

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility and identity of the applicant
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found lacking credibility due to inconsistencies and implausibilities
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution upon return to North Korea
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in testimony and lack of corroborative documentation
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s. 72(1) of the Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Speculative findings and insufficient consideration of evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden on applicant to prove identity and risk
Crimes.Application_Factor: Corroborative evidence dismissed without sufficient basis
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation of identity and nationality documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Establishment of credible identity as a North Korean citizen
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 96 and 97
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in narrative and implausibilities in testimony
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, referred back for reconsideration
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove identity and nationality
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Doubts about dialect expertise and authenticity of supporting letters
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must prove identity and nationality for refugee status
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Credible fear of persecution in North Korea
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed to be North Korean defector seeking protection
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Allowance of judicial review and referral for re-hearing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving credibility and entry method
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Speculative rejection of key evidence without proper justification
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Corroborative evidence submitted but inadequately assessed
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged smuggling involvement through irregular border crossing
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No explicit criminal record, but credibility concerns raised
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential misrepresentation and lack of verified identity
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Fear of persecution if returned to North Korea
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Board Member at Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Outcome: Reconsideration ordered by different Board member
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to properly assess evidence and reliance on speculation

Crimes.Violation_Type: Credibility undermining through false statements or omissions
Crimes.Governing_Law: Statutory interpretation and procedural fairness under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed North Korean origin but faced credibility challenges
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Entered Canada and made a refugee claim
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper discounting of affidavits and speculative assumptions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentary proof of nationality
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found inconsistent and implausible by Board
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, matter referred for reconsideration
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of negative refugee determination
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before a different decision maker

Application_Facts: Applicants fled Bangladesh due to alleged persecution by the Awami League for involvement with the Bangladesh Nationalist Party.
Discrepancies noted between testimony and Basis of Claim Form.
Applicants did not seek asylum in the U.S. despite opportunity.
Claimant_Status: Principal Applicant and family claiming refugee protection
Residency_Compliance: Complied with Canadian immigration procedures upon entry
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistencies in testimony and documentation
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider explanations for discrepancies
Overreliance on failure to claim asylum in the U.S.
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence of political affiliation and threats
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD discounted documentary evidence without sufficient justification
Lack of proper explanation for discrediting applicant's account
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant evasive and inconsistent
Federal Court found credibility assessment unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status based on credibility findings
Outcome: Referred back to new RPD panel
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on grounds of race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Decision_Rationale: RPD's credibility analysis was unreasonable
Explanations provided by applicants were ignored
Failure to claim asylum in the U.S. was given undue weight

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to threats from individuals allegedly linked to police extortion in El Salvador
Misrepresentation_Element: Omissions in IMM 5611 form, inconsistencies between forms, police reports, and oral testimony
Procedural_Issue: RPD did not allow applicant to explain discrepancies in evidence
Evidence_Used: IMM 5611 form, police reports, oral testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Discrepancies in documentation and testimony not clarified
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on omissions and inconsistencies
Legal_Standard_Applied: Subjective and objective fear of persecution
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for credibility
Decision_Rationale: RPD violated procedural fairness by relying on discrepancies without giving applicant chance to respond

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Roma family from Hungary claimed refugee status in Canada, citing persecution and lack of state protection; Board focused on applicants' interactions with police rather than operational adequacy of Hungary's protection measures
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to properly assess operational adequacy of state protection; focused on claimants' reporting behavior instead
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence showing inadequate protection for Roma in Hungary
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored relevant documentary evidence on systemic persecution and state response
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claims by a different panel
Decision_Rationale: Board erred by focusing on applicants' interactions with police rather than assessing the operational adequacy of Hungary's protection mechanisms for Roma

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant challenged negative PRRA and H&C decisions citing procedural unfairness and incorrect assessments
Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness breach did not affect outcome
Evidence_Used: hardship and child interests in H&C assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant failed to provide new evidence rebutting prior IFA finding
Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably assessed H&C application without undue reliance on impossibility standard
Decision_Outcome: PRRA and H&C decisions were reasonable and procedurally fair
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA and H&C decisions
Decision_Rationale: No new evidence to rebut IFA; procedural fairness breach inconsequential; H&C assessment balanced relevant factors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Mr. Figueroa applied for permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds; Delegate focused solely on past membership in an organization linked to terrorism, ignoring non-combatant role, family ties, and community contributions
Procedural_Issue: Lack of transparency and balanced analysis in decision-making
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider mitigating factors such as non-combatant status and strong H&C considerations
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of H&C application based on security inadmissibility
Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Overemphasis on security concerns without adequate balancing of positive H&C factors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in terrorism
National_Security_Element: Alleged membership in FMLN, an organization associated with terrorism
National_Security_Danger: Perceived threat due to organizational affiliation
Threat_Assessment: Based on membership without assessment of individual conduct or role
Risk_Factor: Affiliation with a designated terrorist organization
Target_Entity: Government or state institutions during conflict period
Admission_or_Involvement: Past membership acknowledged, but limited to non-combatant activities
Evidence_Credibility: No challenge to credibility of membership, but context not fully assessed
Key_Evidence_Issue: Failure to distinguish between combatant and non-combatant roles within the organization
Evidence_Type: Documentary and declaratory evidence regarding political involvement
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section related to security inadmissibility
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 34(1)(f) of IRPA – membership in terrorist organization
Dispute_Type: Interpretation and application of security inadmissibility in H&C context
Consequences_of_Action: Denial of permanent residency despite strong humanitarian factors

Violation_Type: Decision based on incorrect factual findings
Application_Facts: Fungai Nyoka fled Zimbabwe due to alleged persecution by ZANU-PF for her MDC involvement; claimed fear of future persecution; testimony contradicted by tribunal over ZANU-PF militia formation date
Evidentiary_Deficiency: New evidence introduced at Federal Court level contradicting tribunal's findings
Failure to consider relevant country conditions
Credibility_Assessment: Testimony discredited due to alleged contradictions, particularly regarding ZANU-PF militia formation date
Outcome: Case remitted for reconsideration by a different panel
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim by a new tribunal panel
Decision_Rationale: Errors in fact-finding
Failure to consider relevant evidence
Absence of proper section 97 analysis
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Violation_Type: Failure to apply proper legal standard
Legal_Provision_Violated: Presumption of truth in refugee claims
Obligation to consider evidence as presented
Application_Facts: Mahmud claimed persecution in Bangladesh and applied for refugee status; CRDD denied claim due to alleged lack of corroboration and inconsistencies in letters
Procedural_Issue: CRDD focused on omissions in supporting letters rather than their content, contrary to legal precedent
Evidence_Used: Letters from family and community members
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Perceived gaps in documentary evidence used improperly to undermine credibility
Credibility_Assessment: CRDD improperly assessed credibility by dismissing evidence based on form rather than substance
Outcome: Federal Court set aside CRDD's decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a new hearing
Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicant's allegations presumed true unless contradicted by evidence
Decision_Rationale: CRDD erred by not considering the content of supporting documents and violating established credibility assessment principles

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and made multiple unsuccessful immigration applications
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review conducted under reasonableness standard
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly questioned, but evidence deemed insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Lack of credible and sufficient evidence to establish risk upon removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work without authorization under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had failed refugee claims and was under deportation order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to unauthorized work and status violations
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed procedural fairness and evidence sufficiency
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited personal evidence; lack of corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility not directly challenged, but evidence considered insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No credible threat established; delays in filing undermined claim strength

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged insufficient consideration of submitted evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: PIF and mother's letter were considered
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Cooperation with U.S. authorities in drug case
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Criminal inadmissibility due to involvement in drug conspiracy
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Fear of reprisals in Dominican Republic due to cooperation with U.S. law enforcement
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Insufficient evidence of personal risk; no procedural unfairness found

Application_Facts: The Seiffert family had extensive international travel but established businesses and residences in Canada.
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet the 1095-day residency requirement due to absences
Procedural_Issue: Breach of natural justice during oral hearing, failure to properly analyze residency connections
Evidence_Used: Businesses and residences established in Canada, travel history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge focused on absences rather than Canadian connections, failed to apply Re Koo and Re Papadogiorgakis factors
Outcome: Seiffert family deemed to meet residency requirements and entitled to Canadian citizenship
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship based on proper assessment of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application under Section 5(1)(c)
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with consideration of natural justice
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge erred by focusing on absences and failing to assess the applicant's overall connection to Canada, resulting in a reviewable error.

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants were failed refugee claimants seeking humanitarian and compassionate exemption based on skills and family ties
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to overstaying after rejected claim
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging H&C officer's refusal
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of undue hardship upon removal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on relevance of factors
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Humanitarian and compassionate exemption to remain in Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of H&C officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No undue hardship established if applicants left Canada; officer acted within jurisdiction

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants sought exemption based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds; public policy argument raised late
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to remaining after removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review following denial of H&C application
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Public policy argument not raised initially; lack of recognized category for skilled workers
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found no error in assessment; arguments not substantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from removal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of H&C officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No undue hardship established; public policy argument not properly raised or applicable

Application_Facts: The Applicants' refugee claims were dismissed by the RPD and upheld by the RAD, prompting a judicial review.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD erred by applying a reasonableness standard instead of conducting an independent assessment.
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter referred back to a different RAD panel
Remedy_Sought: Independent reassessment by a different RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: The RAD has equal expertise to the RPD in assessing documentary evidence and must conduct an independent assessment rather than reviewing for reasonableness.

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate intent to leave Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 11(1), Regulations s. 179
Crimes.Application_Facts: Dhillon failed to provide sufficient economic or family ties with India and lacked travel history
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not established – applicant did not prove compliance with temporary residency conditions
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No interview was required; no breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of ties to home country and intent to return
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found insufficient basis to trust applicant would leave Canada
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn visa refusal through judicial review
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Court intervention to reassess visa decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicant must prove they will leave Canada at the end of their authorized stay
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual assessments, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not meet burden of proof; reasonable grounds to believe overstay may occur

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with Immigration and Refugee Protection Act requirements
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer committed a reviewable error in rejecting the application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 11(1), Regulations s. 179
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to establish credibility due to lack of evidence
Evidence_Type: Insufficient documentation of ties to India
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 11(1) and s. 179 of the Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged reviewable error by visa officer
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to meet burden of proof regarding intent to return to India
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to submit required affidavits and supporting documents
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of applicant's likelihood to comply with visa conditions
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden of proof on applicant to demonstrate compliance with IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of travel history and weak socio-economic ties
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Visa Officer, Federal Court of Canada
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual findings, correctness for legal questions

Application_Facts: Mr. Abdulghafoor's citizenship application was approved by a citizenship judge despite limited evidence of physical presence in Canada; the Minister challenged the decision based on insufficient residency evidence.
Residency_Compliance: Discrepancies in physical presence evidence were not significant enough to undermine the reasonableness of the decision.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed the reasonableness of the citizenship judge's decision.
Evidence_Used: Landlord letters, tax assessments, border records, credibility findings
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited evidence of physical presence in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: The citizenship judge found Mr. Abdulghafoor credible despite some discrepancies.
Decision_Outcome: The citizenship judge's decision to grant citizenship was upheld.
Outcome: The court dismissed the Minister's application for judicial review.
Relief_Sought: The Minister sought to overturn the citizenship judge's decision.
Decision_Rationale: The decision was justified, transparent, and intelligible based on the evidence and credibility assessment.

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Breach of duty to consult established
Grounds_for_Claim: Potential adverse impact on Treaty 8 rights
Risk_Factor: Exclusion from environmental and regulatory decision-making
Credibility: Supported by evidence of minimal consultation opportunities
Legal_Provision: Duty to consult under Canadian common law and constitutional principles
Risk_Nature: Threat to Aboriginal rights and title
Victim_Basis: Collective Indigenous rights under treaty and law

Application_Facts: Applicant arrived in Canada on the M/V Sun Sea without proper authorization
Claimant_Status: Applicant sought refugee protection in Canada
Evidence_Used: Board considered evidence regarding arrival on M/V Sun Sea
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of risk of persecution or government suspicion in Sri Lanka
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by Immigration and Refugee Board
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: No reasonable fear of persecution due to perceived LTTE association; insufficient evidence of current government suspicion

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to immigration officials
Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on perceived LTTE association
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in rejecting the applicant's claim
Credibility_Assessment: Board assessed credibility of claims regarding LTTE association
Evidence_Type: Speech by Sri Lankan Minister (pre-arrival, not indicative of current policy)
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to perceived LTTE ties from traveling on M/V Sun Sea
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Timing and relevance of Sri Lankan Minister’s speech
Application_Factor: Perceived association with LTTE based on mode of entry

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving organized arrival via M/V Sun Sea
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied; no intervention warranted
Criminal_Activity: Arrival on vessel linked to organized people smuggling
Risk_Nexus: Alleged risk of persecution in Sri Lanka
Evidence_Source: Board’s assessment of applicant's background and travel
Basis_for_Decision: Insufficient evidence of systemic torture or government suspicion

National_Security_Element: Perceived association with LTTE, a designated terrorist organization
National_Security_Danger: Alleged risk of being perceived as affiliated with LTTE upon return to Sri Lanka
Threat_Assessment: Board found no sufficient evidence of actual or perceived affiliation
Risk_Factor: Travel on M/V Sun Sea raising potential perception of LTTE links
Nature_of_Acts: Seeking refugee status based on feared retaliation due to perceived ties
Admission_or_Involvement: No admission of involvement; claim based on external perception
Evidence_Credibility: Applicant cleared by Canadian authorities; no prior suspicion in Sri Lanka
Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of evidence that Sri Lankan government perceives M/V Sun Sea arrivals as LTTE members
Evidence_Type: Official clearances, lack of prior targeting
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant’s fear not objectively supported
Credibility_Factors: No history of persecution, no direct threats, clearance by authorities
Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, security grounds
Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving national security concerns
Consequences_of_Action: Denial of refugee status and dismissal of judicial review

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution by Venezuelan groups due to Ms. Garcia's refusal to disclose confidential information.
Procedural_Issue: RPD focused on employment issues rather than the kidnapping and threats.
RPD ignored key evidence like medical certificates.
RPD failed to address discrepancies adequately.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inadequate addressing of discrepancies in evidence
Decision_Outcome: The application for judicial review is allowed.
Outcome: Matter remitted for reconsideration by a different panel.
Legal_Standard_Applied: The RPD must consider all material evidence and provide reasons for rejecting or accepting it.
Decision_Rationale: Court found flaws in RPD's reasoning, including failure to properly assess key evidence and mischaracterization of the nature of the claims.

Crimes.Application_Facts: Nabiloo was sentenced to over two years for drug possession; appeal of conviction was pending.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal to IAD dismissed due to lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD lacked jurisdiction under s. 64(2) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; Federal Court dismissed judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious criminality based on imposed sentence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: 'Punished' refers to the sentence imposed, not the outcome of a pending appeal

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether s. 64(2) IRPA bars appeal during criminal appeal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Imposed sentence of over two years considered sufficient
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD appeal dismissed; judicial review denied
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to establish eligibility for appeal
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 64(2) IRPA applies if sentence is at least two years
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to IAD's lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA provisions on inadmissibility and appeals
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued punishment not final due to pending appeal

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacked jurisdiction; Federal Court dismissed application
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of drug offenses with three-year sentence
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Sentence of three years triggers s. 64(2) IRPA bar

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA and H&C decisions
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's claims of persecution and humanitarian grounds were deemed unsupported by credible evidence
Decision_Outcome: PRRA and H&C decisions were reasonable
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible evidence supporting claims
Legal_Rule: Decisions must be reasonable, based on evidence, and fall within acceptable legal outcomes
Defendant_Response: Officer properly analyzed new evidence and applied legal standards
Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA relating to PRRA and H&C considerations

Legal_Issue: Whether Sanofi is liable to Apotex for losses due to delayed market entry of generic ramipril under Section 8 of the PM (NOC) Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies on market dynamics, pricing, and regulatory impacts
Decision_Outcome: Sanofi is liable to compensate Apotex for lost profits during the Relevant Period
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to demonstrate entitlement to damages under Section 8
Credibility_Factor: Court relied on expert evidence to construct hypothetical market scenario
Legal_Rule: Section 8 allows second person to claim damages if prohibition application by first person fails and causes market delay
Standard_of_Review: Objective assessment of market conditions and damages based on evidentiary record
Grounds_for_Claim: Delayed market entry of Apotex's generic ramipril due to Sanofi's unsuccessful prohibition application
Outcome_on_Merits: Apotex succeeded on the merits; Sanofi found liable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Market share projections, timing of market entries by authorized generics, trade spend, API costs
Defendant_Response: Sanofi contested liability and damages, but court found in favor of Apotex
Evidence_Type: Expert testimony, regulatory timelines, market data
Remedy_Requested: Damages for lost profits due to delayed market entry
Outcome: Court ordered Sanofi to calculate and pay damages to Apotex as per court's guidelines

Legal_Issue: Failure to provide separate analysis under section 97 of IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Sections 96 and 97
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in applicant's testimony led to credibility doubts
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, lack of distinct evidence for Section 97 claim
Legal_Provision: Section 96 (Convention refugee), Section 97 (risk of torture or cruel treatment)
Application_Error: Alleged failure to conduct separate analysis under Section 97
Legal_Standard: Separate analysis required under Section 97 if evidence differs from Section 96 claim
Application_Factor: Presence or absence of distinct evidence supporting Section 97
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Prior_Criminality: Misapprehended facts regarding double assault conviction
Evidence_Sufficiency: Failure to consider applicant's fears and H&C application
Failure to fully consider personal circumstances and fears

Prior_Criminality: Convicted of manslaughter and other crimes
Evidence_Sufficiency: Failure to assess risks or relevance of H&C application

Risk_Assessment: High risk if returned to Pakistan
Risk_Nature: Reprisals due to criminal proceedings and assault allegation
Credibility_Assessment: Positive credibility based on supporting evidence

Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility due to family member's conviction
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 48(2)
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show special circumstances
Credibility_Factor: Credible explanation for delay in PRRA filing
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to consider humanitarian and compassionate factors
Defendant_Response: Focused on procedural delays and lack of subpoena

Legal_Issue: Refusal to defer removal despite personal circumstances
Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to consider health and safety risks
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate exigent circumstances
Credibility_Factor: Credible fear of reprisals and health concerns
Defendant_Response: Relied on absence of subpoena and delayed PRRA

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Credibility_Assessment: Principal applicant’s inconsistent statements undermined credibility
Evidence_Type: Credible evidence of state protection in Peru, evidence regarding Shining Path threats and DINCOTE persecution
Legal_Provision: Lack of state protection, absence of valid internal flight alternative (IFA) under IRPA
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged persecution by Shining Path and Peruvian anti-terrorist police
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Availability of state protection in Peru and reasonable internal flight alternative in Lima
Application_Factor: Credibility, state protection, internal flight alternative
Decision_Outcome: Applicants not recognized as refugees or persons in need of protection
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the Registrar's decision to refuse Marcas's trademark application due to insufficient use of the design mark was reasonable
Evidence_Assessment: Only three transactions over nearly five years; no sales after 1999
Burden_of_Proof: Marcas failed to demonstrate continuous use
Credibility_Factor: Marcas admitted halting CASTILLO rum sales in Canada in 1999
Legal_Rule: A trademark must be continuously used in the normal course of trade under subsection 30(b)
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient use of the design mark in Canada
Outcome_on_Merits: Registrar's refusal of trademark application was reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Transaction records, admission of halted sales
Evidence_Type: Commercial transaction records, admissions by applicant
Authority: Registrar of Trademarks, reviewed by court

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or misleading information in immigration or citizenship application
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of citizenship application denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Court correctly applied the legal test for residency and reasonably weighed the evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The Citizenship Judge found contradictions and misleading statements in Mr. Zhu's application
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Selective and passive documents (e.g., bank statements), lack of active residency proof
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient evidence of active residency and credibility concerns
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible, consistent, and active evidence of residency
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Provided false or misleading information and failed to disclose relevant facts
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Active indicators of residency such as employment or school records
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Mixed questions of law and fact subject to reasonableness standard
Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliance on passive documentation without corroboration

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Appeal from Citizenship Court decision on residency grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Correct application of legal test for residency and appropriate weighing of evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient active residency evidence; reliance on passive documents
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove physical presence and intent to reside
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must demonstrate factual residence through objective evidence
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet minimum physical presence requirements under the Act
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to insufficient evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Bank statements, lack of employment or educational records
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Residency obligations under Canadian citizenship law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Mr. Zhu appealed the denial of his application
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Passive financial records without corroborative active ties

Crimes.Violation_Type: Possession and submission of an altered passport in a citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section related to document integrity
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Zhu submitted an altered passport with unexplained discrepancies
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Altered travel document affecting credibility and truthfulness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under citizenship and immigration laws
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible explanation for passport alteration
Crimes.Outcome: Denial upheld due to credibility and compliance issues
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge properly assessed residency and credibility, including document fraud
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission and Federal Court on review

Dispute_Type: Removal risk assessment based on risk of torture
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicants face a substantial risk of torture or mistreatment if returned to China
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 97(1)
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA officer relied on diplomatic assurances and notoriety of the case; failed to assess reliability of assurances or consider reports of systematic torture
Decision_Outcome: PRRA decision found no substantial risk of torture
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish substantial grounds for believing in risk of torture
Credibility_Factor: Diplomatic assurances from China considered, but lack of monitoring mechanisms undermined credibility
Legal_Rule: A person is in need of protection under IRPA s. 97(1) if removal would subject them to torture, risk to life, or cruel and unusual treatment
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of torture and unfair trial upon return to China
Key_Evidence_Considered: Diplomatic assurances, notoriety of the case, past compliance with diplomatic notes
Legal_Framework: IRPA, international law on torture, principles of non-refoulement
Defendant_Response: Applicants claimed refugee status and argued they would face torture
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; PRRA decision set aside

Dispute_Type: Removal risk assessment based on risk of torture
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicants face a risk of torture or mistreatment if returned to China
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 97(1)
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA officer relied on notoriety and past compliance with diplomatic notes; failed to assess reliability of assurances in context of widespread torture
Decision_Outcome: PRRA decision concluded no risk of torture upon return
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish substantial grounds for believing in risk of torture
Credibility_Factor: Diplomatic assurances deemed insufficient due to lack of monitoring and enforcement mechanisms
Legal_Rule: Under IRPA s. 97(1), a person must not be removed if there are substantial grounds to believe they would be tortured
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of torture and mistreatment upon return to China
Key_Evidence_Considered: Diplomatic assurances, high-profile nature of the case, history of China honoring such assurances
Legal_Framework: IRPA, international human rights law, principle of non-refoulement
Defendant_Response: Applicants sought protection based on fear of torture and unfair prosecution
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; decision found flawed in assessing reliability of assurances

Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Key_Evidence_Considered: unsourced medical tip about alcohol withdrawal

Grounds_for_Claim: reliance on speculative and unsourced data

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in use of extrinsic evidence
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No substantial wrong or miscarriage of justice
Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation via reliance on sister's removal order

Application_Facts: Applied for permanent residence on humanitarian grounds
Procedural_Issue: Use of extrinsic evidence without explicit notice
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness
Officer acted within acceptable range

Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues due to omissions in testimony
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution by Sipah-e-Sahaba as a Shia individual
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence, adequate state protection
Application_Error: Omissions in applicant's account affecting credibility
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court of Canada

Legal_Issue: Whether failure to use the trademark 'Fascination' for three years constitutes special circumstances excusing non-use under s. 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Appellant provided no evidence of when use would resume or specific obstacles preventing use; recession deemed a common situation, not special circumstances
Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to prove special circumstances justifying non-use
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible evidence from appellant regarding future use or external obstacles
Legal_Rule: Under s. 45(3), a trademark may be expunged if not in use and absence of use is not due to special circumstances beyond the owner's control
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and application of s. 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-use of trademark for over three years without justification by special circumstances
Outcome_on_Merits: Appellant failed to meet burden; claim rejected
Key_Evidence_Considered: Economic conditions cited as reason for non-use; lack of evidence on timing of resumption or specific impediments
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act, administrative and appellate review procedures
Defendant_Response: Economic downturn (recession) as reason for non-use
Evidence_Type: Oral/affidavit evidence on economic conditions, lack of documentary evidence on future plans
Outcome: Trademark 'Fascination' expunged; costs awarded to respondent

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible but insufficient for personalized risk

Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to demonstrate inadequate state protection
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of extortion targeting small business owners
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee protection under IRPA sections 96 and 97

Crimes.Risk_Nature: Due to perceived wealth, not individual targeting
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent but not indicative of personalization
